```{r setup, include = FALSE}
fa_list <- function(x, incremental = FALSE) {
  icons <- names(x)
  fragment <- ifelse(incremental, "fragment", "")
  items <- glue::glue('<li class="{fragment}"><span class="fa-li"><i class="{icons}"></i></span> {x}</li>')
  paste('<ul class="fa-ul">', 
        paste(items, collapse = "\n"),
        "</ul>", sep = "\n")
}


detach_package <- function(pkg, character.only = FALSE)
{
  if(!character.only)
  {
    pkg <- deparse(substitute(pkg))
  }
  search_item <- paste("package", pkg, sep = ":")
  while(search_item %in% search())
  {
    detach(search_item, unload = TRUE, character.only = TRUE)
  }
}
```

## [What is Systematic Reivew?]{auto-animate="true"}

- A structured, comprehensive method for identifying and summarising all available evidence on a specific research question.

- Systematic reviews and meta-analyses are pillars of evidence-based medicine. 


- ![](images/SR_steps.png){fig-align="center"}

::: notes

Systematic reviews and meta-analyses are widely regarded as the "gold standard" for generating high-quality evidence to inform clinical practice and policy decisions.

The steps includes topic selection, conceptualised and create protocol, searching for studies,screening for studies,appraise studies, data extraction, synthesis and interpret results. 

:::


## [Example of a sysrematic review and meta-analysis]{auto-animate="true"}

<iframe src="https://jogh.org/2025/jogh-15-04166" width="1200" height="600" style="border:none;">

</iframe>


::: notes

In this systematic review and mate-analysis, we are trying to identify the true prevalence of COVID-associated Acute Kidney Injury. Yes, you heard me correct. Once of the common complication of COVID among hospitalised patients is Acute Kidney Injury (AKI), which is a sudden loss of kidney function measured by the change in serum creatinine. 

The reason driving this pice of meta-analysis was that when I was looking up the AKI prevalence among the published literatures, this number varies from 1% to 70%. Of course the AKI prevalence would be different based on different clinical setting. i.e. ICU vs non-ICU, different COVID management policy such as straight lockdown vs Herd immunity. Regardless, we want to provide a global overview of the COVID-19 AKI prevalence reported in published studies to uncover geographic and socioeconomic disparities.

In order to do that, we extracted data from more than 300 publihsed papers using Covidence.

Just in case if you are not familiar with Covidence, let me show you an exmaple. 


:::

## [Data extraction - Covidence]{auto-animate="true"}


[![](images/covidence.png){fig-align="center"}](https://app.covidence.org/sign_in)

::: notes

This is a very manual process as you can see, it requires a lot of huamn effort. 

For a more robust process, dual extraction is required sometime. This means that this process will be done twice by two individuals. 


:::


## [Design of metaextractoR]{auto-animate="true"}

![](images/flowchat.png){fig-align="center" width="1400" height="600"}

::: notes

Given the labour intensive process for data extraction, to remove some of the labour work, we developed this R package, metaextractoR that embeded Large Language Models to help with data extraction. 

The design of this workflow follows the Cochrance systematic review guideline. At each step, there is a human-in-the-loop process incorprated. 

There are three shinyapps that provide user-friendly interface for anyone to extract data using LLMs. 

:::
